name: Auto-Generate Social Posts from GitHub README/CHANGELOG Updates with GPT-4o and OAuth

user.name: Jorge Mart√≠nez
user.bio: AI Engineer & Full Stack Developer skilled in designing intelligent agents, workflow automation, and NLP solutions. Experienced with LLMs, Relevance AI, make, zapier, and n8n. Proficient in integrating AI and chatbots into web apps, optimizing processes, and leveraging automation for real-time productivity. Strong background in backend and frontend development, REST APIs, and database management.

description:
# Generate social posts from GitHub pushes to Twitter and LinkedIn
On each GitHub *push*, this workflow checks if the commit set includes **README.md** and **CHANGELOG.md**, fetches both files, lets an **LLM** generate a Twitter and LinkedIn post, then publishes to **Twitter** and **LinkedIn (Person)**.
## Apps & Nodes
* **Trigger:** Webhook
* **Logic:** IF, Merge, Aggregate
* **GitHub:** Get Repository File (√ó2)
* **Files:** Extract from File (text) (√ó2)
* **AI:** OpenAI Chat Model ‚Üí LLM Chain (+ Structured Output Parser)
* **Publish:** Twitter, LinkedIn (Person)
## Prerequisites
* **GitHub:** OAuth2 or PAT with repo read.
* **OpenAI:** API key.
* **Twitter:** OAuth2 app with *Read and Write*; scopes `tweet.read tweet.write users.read offline.access`.
* **LinkedIn (Person):** OAuth2 credentials; **required scope:** `w_member_social`, `openid`.
## Setup
1. **GitHub Webhook:** Repo ‚Üí *Settings ‚Üí Webhooks*

   * Payload URL: `https://<your-n8n-domain>/webhook/github/push`
   * Content type: `application/json` ‚Ä¢ Event: *Push* ‚Ä¢ Secret (optional) ‚Ä¢ Branches as needed.
2. **Credentials:** Connect GitHub, OpenAI, Twitter, and LinkedIn (Person).
## How it Works
1. **Webhook** receives GitHub push payload.
2. **IF** checks that `README` and `CHANGELOG` appear in *added/modified*.
3. **GitHub (Get Repository File)** pulls `README.md` and `CHANGELOG.md`.
4. **Extract from File (text)** converts both binaries to text.
5. **Merge & Aggregate** combines into one item with both contents.
6. **LLM (OpenAI + Parser)** returns a JSON with `twitter` and `linkedin`.
7. **Twitter** posts the tweet.
8. **LinkedIn (Person)** posts the LinkedIn text.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.

workflow.name: Generate social posts from GitHub pushes to Twitter and LinkedIn

messageValues.message:
=# Role

You are a precise content generator for social media.
Your input will be a JSON object with two string fields:

* `README`: full project README in Markdown.
* `CHANGELOG`: full changelog in Markdown.

## Your task

Produce **one JSON object** with exactly two keys:

```json
{
  "twitter": "<tweet in English, <=280 chars including the GitHub link>",
  "linkedin": "<LinkedIn post in English, long-form>"
}
```

No extra keys, no surrounding text, no Markdown fences.

## Parsing rules (do not hallucinate)

1. **Repository URL (required in both posts):**

   * Extract the **first** URL that matches a GitHub repo pattern from `CHANGELOG` using a regex like:
     `https?://github\.com/[A-Za-z0-9_.-]+/[A-Za-z0-9_.-]+`
   * If not found in `CHANGELOG`, search `README` with the same regex.
   * If still not found, **do not fabricate** a URL; instead, use the literal placeholder `https://github.com/REPO_MISSING`. (Keep generating the posts.)

2. **Project name:**

   * Prefer the first H1 (`# Title`) in `README`. If not present, infer a concise name from the first heading found. If impossible, use a short neutral name like ‚ÄúThis project‚Äù.

3. **First release or update determination:**

   * From `CHANGELOG`, detect if this is the **first or only version** (e.g., version numbers like `v1.0.0`, "Initial release", or only one version section present).
   * If first/only version ‚Üí the post should clearly state it's a **new project/app/development** (e.g., ‚ÄúNew project‚Äù, ‚ÄúLaunching a new application‚Äù).
   * If not first version ‚Üí the post should state it‚Äôs an **update or improvement** (e.g., ‚ÄúUpdating the project X‚Äù, ‚ÄúImproving the application X‚Äù).

4. **Description & features:**

   * Derive a clear, one-sentence value proposition from `README`‚Äôs Description/Overview.
   * Collect 4‚Äì7 key capabilities/benefits (bullets for LinkedIn).

5. **Tech stack:**

   * From `README`, extract notable technologies (backend, frontend, infra/services).
   * Examples to detect if present: Django, DRF, Celery, Redis, Channels/WebSockets, Next.js, React, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, Zustand, Framer Motion, Stripe, OpenAI, OAuth/Google, SMTP/Email, Docker, Docker Compose.
   * For **Twitter**, mention only the **3‚Äì4 most central** technologies.
   * For **LinkedIn**, you may group by Backend / Frontend / Infra.

## LinkedIn post (English, long-form)

* Tone: professional, enthusiastic, concise sentences; **no emojis**.
* Structure (use short paragraphs and bullet points):

  * Hook:

    * If first release ‚Üí start with ‚ÄúNew project: ‚Ä¶‚Äù or similar phrasing.
    * If update ‚Üí start with ‚ÄúUpdating the project \[name]: ‚Ä¶‚Äù or similar phrasing.
  * What it does: 1 short paragraph.
  * Key features/benefits: 4‚Äì7 bullets.
  * Tech stack (grouped): bullets for Backend, Frontend, Infra/Services.
  * Motivational developer line (one sentence, non-cheesy).
  * Call to action with the **repo link** (exactly once).
* Hashtags: **8‚Äì12** relevant tags, all lowercase, no spaces (use hyphens only if part of the tech brand). Prioritize technologies and domain, e.g.:
  `#python #django #nextjs #typescript #tailwindcss #stripe #openai #celery #redis #websockets #ai #saas #startups #webdevelopment`
  (Pick only those truly present; don‚Äôt invent.)

## Twitter post (English, max 280 chars including link)

* Format:

  * If first release ‚Üí short sentence like ‚ÄúNew project: ‚Ä¶‚Äù or similar.
  * If update ‚Üí short sentence like ‚ÄúUpdating project \[name]: ‚Ä¶‚Äù or similar.
* Describe what the app does + **repo link** (once).
* Mention **3‚Äì4** main technologies inline (e.g., Django, Next.js, Stripe, OpenAI).
* **2‚Äì3 hashtags max**, chosen from the most relevant.
* **No emojis.**
* Length enforcement: if >280 chars, iteratively shorten by (in order): remove adjectives, compress wording, then drop one hashtag at a time until ‚â§280. Never drop the repo link.

## Output formatting

* Return a **single JSON object** with keys `"twitter"` and `"linkedin"`.
* Escape quotes properly.
* Do **not** add explanations, markdown, or extra whitespace before/after the JSON.
* Do not include any links other than the repo link.

## Safety & accuracy

* Never fabricate tech or features not present in the inputs.
* If some sections are missing in inputs, omit that detail gracefully.
* Keep everything in **English** except hashtags which are typically lowercase English tokens.
* Do not output dates/releases unless explicitly present.
* Maintain a positive, credible tone.

parameters.content:
# GitHub Push ‚Üí README & CHANGELOG check

## 1) Webhook (receive push from GitHub)
* **Node:** Webhook (POST)
* **GitHub setup:** Repository ‚Üí *Settings ‚Üí Webhooks ‚Üí Add webhook*
  * **Payload URL:** `https://<your-n8n-domain>/webhook/github/push`
  * **Content type:** `application/json`
  * **Event:** *Just the push event*
  * **Secret:** optional
  * **Branches:** choose specific branches or send all
## 2) IF (filter)
* **Node:** IF
* **Checks:** push contains `README` and `CHANGELOG` in *added* or *modified* files
* **True:** continue
* **False:** do nothing (stop)

# GitHub ‚Üí Extract ‚Üí Merge/Aggregate

## 1) GitHub (Get Repository File)
* **Credentials:** GitHub OAuth2 or PAT with read access.
* **Owner/Repo/Branch:** from webhook payload (`body.repository`, branch from `body.ref`).
* **File Path:** `README.md` and `CHANGELOG.md` (use two GitHub nodes).
* **Output:** binary files.
## 2) Extract from File (text)
* **Operation:** `text`.
* **Input:** binary from each GitHub node.
* **Output:** plain text for README and CHANGELOG.
## 3) Merge & Aggregate
* **Merge:** *Wait for Both* (combine README + CHANGELOG into one item).
* **Aggregate:** `aggregateAllItemData` (single item with `documents` list holding both contents).

# LLM ‚Üí Post to Twitter & LinkedIn

## 1) LLM (OpenAI ‚Üí JSON)
* Nodes: OpenAI Chat Model ‚Üí Basic LLM Chain (+ Structured Output Parser)
* Input: aggregated README + CHANGELOG
* Output: JSON with `"twitter"` and `"linkedin"`
## 2) Publish
* **Twitter node**
  * Auth: credentials
* **LinkedIn node (Person)**
  * Auth: credentials
  * Required scope: `w_member_social`, `openid`

# Generate social posts from GitHub pushes to Twitter and LinkedIn
On each GitHub *push*, this workflow checks if the commit set includes **README.md** and **CHANGELOG.md**, fetches both files, lets an **LLM** generate a Twitter and LinkedIn post, then publishes to **Twitter** and **LinkedIn (Person)**.
## Apps & Nodes
* **Trigger:** Webhook
* **Logic:** IF, Merge, Aggregate
* **GitHub:** Get Repository File (√ó2)
* **Files:** Extract from File (text) (√ó2)
* **AI:** OpenAI Chat Model ‚Üí LLM Chain (+ Structured Output Parser)
* **Publish:** Twitter, LinkedIn (Person)
## Prerequisites
* **GitHub:** OAuth2 or PAT with repo read.
* **OpenAI:** API key.
* **Twitter:** OAuth2 app with *Read and Write*; scopes `tweet.read tweet.write users.read offline.access`.
* **LinkedIn (Person):** OAuth2 credentials; **required scope:** `w_member_social`, `openid`.
## Setup
1. **GitHub Webhook:** Repo ‚Üí *Settings ‚Üí Webhooks*

   * Payload URL: `https://<your-n8n-domain>/webhook/github/push`
   * Content type: `application/json` ‚Ä¢ Event: *Push* ‚Ä¢ Secret (optional) ‚Ä¢ Branches as needed.
2. **Credentials:** Connect GitHub, OpenAI, Twitter, and LinkedIn (Person).
## How it Works
1. **Webhook** receives GitHub push payload.
2. **IF** checks that `README` and `CHANGELOG` appear in *added/modified*.
3. **GitHub (Get Repository File)** pulls `README.md` and `CHANGELOG.md`.
4. **Extract from File (text)** converts both binaries to text.
5. **Merge & Aggregate** combines into one item with both contents.
6. **LLM (OpenAI + Parser)** returns a JSON with `twitter` and `linkedin`.
7. **Twitter** posts the tweet.
8. **LinkedIn (Person)** posts the LinkedIn text.
